One recent case where enforcement mechanisms were used to ensure compliance with environmental regulations in Chile is the Pascua-Lama mining project. The project was a massive mining development along the border of Chile and Argentina, which was proposed by the Canadian mining company Barrick Gold.

In 2013, the project was suspended by the Chilean government over concerns about its potential environmental impacts on water resources and glaciers in the region. In addition to the suspension, Barrick Gold was fined over $16 million for environmental violations related to the project.

In 2020, the Chilean Supreme Court affirmed the suspension of the project and ordered an environmental impact assessment to be completed before any further development could take place. The court also ordered Barrick Gold to pay additional fines and compensate affected communities for environmental damage caused by the project.

This case demonstrates the use of several enforcement mechanisms, including the environmental impact assessment process, environmental sanctions, and the court system, to ensure compliance with environmental regulations in Chile.
